revision.text:
This is a list of some [[long-distance footpath]]s used for [[walking]] and [[hiking]].
==Africa==
===Namibia=== *[[Fish River Canyon]]
===South Africa=== *[[Otter Trail]] *[[Grand Traverse (South Africa)|Grand Traverse]], a 204 Kilometre (127 mi) walk in the [[Drakensberg]]
===Egypt=== *[[Sinai Trail]], a 250km thru-hike in Sinai from Nuweiba to St. Catherine mountain (Egypt highest summit)<ref>http://www.sinaitrail.org</ref>
==Asia==
===Bhutan=== *328 kilometers (216 mi) [[Snowman Trek]], a 21-day hike through the [[Himalayas]] [https://web.archive.org/web/20130502110011/http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/adventure-travel/asia/bhutan-kira-salak.html]
====Hong Kong==== The merit of hiking trails in Hong Kong is that hikers can enjoy scenery of both the sea and highland. *[[Hong Kong Trail]]: across [[Hong Kong Island]] ({{convert|50|km}}) *[[Lantau Trail]]: on [[Lantau Island]] ({{convert|70|km}}) *[[Wilson Trail]]: from [[Stanley, Hong Kong|Stanley]], [[Hong Kong Island]] to [[Nam Chung]], [[New Territories]] ({{convert|78|km}}) *[[MacLehose Trail]]: from [[Sai Kung]] to [[Tuen Mun]] ({{convert|100|km}})
===Georgia===
Transcaucasian Trail:
A long distance trail in the caucasus has been a lingering idea for trekkers and hikers for many years since they started hiking remote parts of the Caucasus. Many sections of the TCT already exist, used by local community members and shepherds for centuries. These trail cross long valleys and traverse mammoth mountains to connect mountain villages together. Unfortunately, in recent years many of these trails have fallen into disrepair, and while many trails are known to locals, they are difficult to navigate for visitors and tourists. In 2015, two Peace Corps volunteers, Paul Stephens and Jeff Haack, mapped and charted known routes in The Republic of Georgia. During this time they succeeded in locating many connections between known trails and publicizing the concept of the trail. In 2016, Tom Allen and Alessandro Mambelli scouted new trail routes in Armenia while the first trail building project began in Svaneti, Georgia. In 2017, the trail building expanded to Dilijan National Park in Armenia while trail building continued in the Svaneti region. Today, over 300 km of trail has been improved and marked in Georgia and Armenia. Many 7-10 day guided hikes are available on the TCT this summer. Over the next 5 years, the trail will be expanded to connect all of the sections and create even longer hikes. The TCT can serve many purposes in the Caucasus region. For one, the natural diversity of the area needs to be protected. This habitat fosters many species of animal and provides unique ecosystems created by the mountains. More information about the trail can be found at transcaucasiantrail.org . Donations can be sustaining or one-time.
===Israel=== *[[Israel National Trail]]: {{convert|1000|km}}, all of them inside the [[Green Line (Israel)|Green Line]], from kibbutz [[Dan (kibbutz)|Dan]] to [[Eilat]] (north to south), covering many historic and scenic points including some urban areas. *[[Jerusalem Trail]]: {{convert|40|km|adj=on}} trail, connects the Israel National Trail with Jerusalem and the area of the old city. *[[Jesus Trail]]: {{convert|65|km}} in the Galilee region, connecting important sites from the life of Jesus. The trail begins in [[Nazareth]] and passes through [[Sepphoris]], [[Cana]], the horns of [[Hattin]], [[Arbel]] Cliffs, [[Capernaum]], [[Tabgha]], the [[Mount of Beatitudes]], the [[Jordan River]], and [[Mount Tabor]]. *[[Golan Trail]]: {{convert|130|km}} from Mt. Hermon (1500m) to the sea of Galilee (-200m) *[[Sea to sea trail]]: {{convert|70|km}} from the [[sea of Galilee]] to the [[Mediterranean Sea]] *[[Valley of the springs TRail]] (Emek HaMaayanot). A trek of about 140 km, around the Valley of springs near the See of Galilee. *[[Haifa Wadis Trail]]: {{convert|50|km|adj=on}} trail, connecting the Israel National Trail with Haifa and its surroundings.
===Japan=== *[[Hokkaidō Nature Trail]]: {{convert|4585|km}} all over the island of Hokkaidō(planning) *[[Tōhoku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|4374|km}} within prefectures of Aomori, Iwate, Miyagi, Akita, Yamagata and Fukushima *[[Chubu Hokuriku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|4029|km}} within prefectures of Gunma, Niigata, Toyama, Ishikawa, Fukui, Nagano, Gifu and Shiga *[[Kantō Fureai Trail]]: {{convert|1665|km}} within prefectures of Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Saitama, Chiba, Tōkyō and Kanagawa. Also known as the Capital Region Nature Trail.<ref>http://ja.japantourist.jp/view/the-kanto-fureai-no-michi-in-tokyo</ref> *[[Tōkaidō Nature Trail]]: {{convert|1697|km}} from Tokyo to Osaka via prefectures of Kanagawa, Yamanashi, Shizuoka, Aichi, Shiga, Gifu, Mie, Kyōto and Nara *[[Kinki Nature Trail]]: {{convert|3291|km}} within prefectures of Fukui, Mie, Shiga, Kyōto, Osaka, Hyōgo, Nara, Wakayama and Tottori *[[Chugoku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|2211|km}} within prefectures of Tottori, Shimane, Okayama, Hiroshima and Yamaguchi *[[Shikoku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|1637|km}} within prefectures of Ehime, Tokushima, Kagawa and Kōchi *[[Kyushu Nature Trail]]: {{convert|2587|km}} within prefectures of Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Kumamoto, Oita, Miyazaki and Kagoshima
===Jordan=== *600 kilometers (372 mi) [[Jordan Trail]]: north-south, cross country from Um Qais to Aqaba<ref>Route descriptions, maps, photos, etc. at [http://www.jordantrail.org/ jordantrail.org]</ref>
===Lebanon=== *[[Lebanon Mountain Trail]], a 26-day {{convert|440|km|adj=on}} trail through [[Mount Lebanon]]
===Malaysia=== *[[Grand Malaysia Trail]] (Kai Pengembara Negara-Kai Trails Around Malaysia): nationwide trail of more than {{convert|3000|km}} length
===Myanmar=== [[Hkakabo Razi]] Trail, climbing the highest peak in Myanmar, in [[Khakaborazi National Park]], and various footpaths in [[Putao]]
===Nepal=== *{{convert|4500|km}} [[The Great Himalaya Trail]] (GHT) is proposed to follow the Greater Himalaya Range from Namche Barwa in [[Tibet]] to Nanga Parbat in [[Pakistan]] forming the world's highest mountain trail. It will connect five Asian countries: [[Bhutan]], [[China]], [[India]], [[Nepal]], and Pakistan. It uses existing trails, many of which are trekking, trade, or pilgrimage routes, but no new trails have been built. Starting near [[Kangchenjunga|Kanchenjunga]] in the east and ending in [[Humla District|Humla]] in the west, the Nepal section has been walked and documented and is about {{convert|1600|km}}. (See the [http://www.thegreathimalayatrail.org/ Great Himalaya Trail website] and the [http://www.greathimalayatrail.com/ Great Himalaya Trail book website].) *Trek to [[Everest Base Camp]], an 18-day trail to the base camp of Mt. Everest (see [http://www.expeditionnepal.com/en/nepal/trekking/everest-base-camp-trek Everest Base Camp Trek at WikiVoyage]|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}) *230 kilometers (145 mi) [[Annapurna Circuit]], a 3-week loop trek through the [[Annapurna]] range (see [https://www.himalayastrek.com/annapurna-circuit-trekking/ Annapurna Circuit at WikiVoyage]) *277 kilometers (173 mi) [[Manaslu Circuit]], a 3-week loop trek through the adjacent range to the [[Annapurna]] region—the [[Manaslu]] region.
===Russia=== *[[Great Baikal Trail]] *[[Frolikha Adventure Coastline Track]] F.A.C.T.: {{convert|100|km}} trail at the northern tip of [[Lake Baikal]]
===South Korea=== * The [[Baekdudaegan]] Trail: {{convert|750|km}} along the ridge of the Baekdu Daegan mountain range, Korea's watershed divide. * [[Olle road|The Jeju Olle]] (400 km) is a series of connected walking courses that circumnavigate the coastline of Jeju Island.
===Turkey=== *[[Sufi Trail]] - 801 km trail from [[Istanbul]] to [[Konya]], following the Ottoman Sultans [[Hajj]] route *[[Lycian Way]] - 540 km trail around the south coast of Turkey *[[Saint Paul Trail]] - 500 km trail following [[Paul the Apostle|St Paul]]'s 1st journey *[http://www.sultanstrail.com Sultans Trail] - from Vienna to İstanbul, following the Ottoman Sultans *[http://cultureroutesinturkey.com/c/hittite-trail/ Hittite Trail - in central Turkey on ancient Hittite roads] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140924050937/http://cultureroutesinturkey.com/c/kackar-mountains-trails/ Kackar Trails - 8 multi-day trails in Northeast Turkey] *[[Evliya Çelebi Way]] - the first part of [[Evliya Çelebi|Evliya]]'s route to Mecca in the 17th century *[http://cultureroutesinturkey.com/c/phrygian-way/ Phrygian Way - 600km route around the Phrygian Valleys near Ankara] *[http://www.cariantrail.com Carian Trail - 800km trail around the south-west coast of Turkey] *[http://www.abrahampath.org Abraham Path - international route starting in Urfa, southeast Turkey] *[http://www.trekkinginturkey.com Trekking in Turkey - website of Turkish trekking routes] *[http://www.trekkingararat.com Trekking Ararat - Trekking guide service in Turkey] *[http://trekopedia.com/?page_id=471 Trekopedia - Trail reference database that covers the Lycian Way]
==Europe== *The [[GR footpath]]s in [[Belgium]], [[France]], [[Spain]] and the [[Netherlands]] *[[European long-distance paths]], over 70.000 km of 12 long-distance E-paths. *The [[Tour du Mont Blanc]] circles the Mont Blanc Massif covering a distance of roughly 170 kilometres (110 mi) with 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) of ascent/descent and passes through parts of Switzerland, Italy and France *The ''[[Haute Randonnée Pyrénéenne]]'' (HRP) in the [[Pyrenees]] in France, Spain and [[Andorra]] *{{convert|800|km}} [[Nordkalottleden Trail]] (Kalottireitti) in the northernmost parts of [[Finland]], [[Sweden]], and [[Norway]] ([[Sápmi (area)|Lapland]]) *{{convert|2530|km}} Camino de Santiago de Compostela, or [[St James's Way]], commonly walked through France and Spain, but including old pilgrimage [[Way of St. James (route descriptions)|routes]] from as far afield as [[Poland]] and [[Portugal]], and adding as many as {{convert|1906|km}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20061211032003/http://www.peterrobins.co.uk/camino/] *''Peaks of the Balkans Trail'', through [[Montenegro]], [[Albania]] and [[Kosovo]] *{{convert|2200|km}} [[Sultans Trail]] in [[Austria]], [[Slovakia]], [[Hungary]], [[Croatia]], [[Serbia]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Greece]], and [[Turkey]] *{{convert|5000|km}} The [[Via Alpina]] network of Alpine trails **{{convert|1500|km}} Red Trail [http://www.backpackinglight.com/cgi-bin/backpackinglight/via_alpina_not_another_walk_in_the_woods.html#.UXcTvoVBEy5] **Violet Trail **Yellow Trail **Green Trail **Blue Trail *[[Via Francigena]] from Canterbury to Rome * [[:it:Tratturo L'Aquila-Foggia]] from L'Aquila (Abruzzo region, Italy) to Foggia (Puglia region, Italy). At 244 km, Tratturo Magno is the longest and the most important ancient route, traversed by shepherds in [[Transhumance]]
===Austria=== *[[Arnoweg]] around the Austrian Alps *[[Alpe Adria Trail]], Austria, Slovenia, Italy *[[North Alpine Trail]] *[[Central Alpine Trail]] *[[South Alpine Trail]] *[[North South Path]] *[[East Austrian Borderland Trail]] *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey *[[Way of the book]]
===Bulgaria=== *[[Kom-Emine]] {{convert|700|km}}, from Mount Kom to [[Cape Emine]] (part of [[European walking route E3]])<ref>[http://www.walkingworld.co.uk/home/index.asp?id=32&nid=183 KOM-EMINE] from Walkingworld</ref> *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Croatia=== *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Czechia=== *[[Polish - Czech Friendship Trail]]: trail along the Polish and Czech border in [[Sudetes]]
===Denmark=== *[[Hærvejen]], ancient trail on the [[Jutland Peninsula]]. *[[Øhavsstien]] 220 km around the archipelago of southern Denmark [[Fünen]]. *[[Gendarmstien]], 74 km following the border between Germany and Denmark. *[https://bornholmrundt.dk Bornholm Rundt]. A walk around of the island of [[Bornholm]] (120 km). *[http://camoenoen.dk Camønoen] A walk on the island of Møn (175 km).
=== Estonia === * [[Peraküla, Lääne County|Peraküla]]-[[Aegviidu]]-[[Ähijärve]], 820 kilometres from North-East to South-West Estonia<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://loodusegakoos.ee/where-to-go/hiking-route/perakula-aegviidu-ahijarve-hiking-route|title=Loodusega Koos|website=Loodusega Koos|access-date=2017-06-05}}</ref> * [[Oandu, Lääne-Viru County|Oandu]]-[[Aegviidu]]-[[Ikla]], 375 kilometres from North to South Estonia<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://loodusegakoos.ee/where-to-go/hiking-route/oandu-aegviidu-ikla-hiking-route|title=Loodusega Koos|website=Loodusega Koos|access-date=2017-06-05}}</ref>
===Finland=== *The [[Karhunkierros]] Trail ({{convert|80|km}}, [https://web.archive.org/web/20070310220324/http://www.luontoon.fi/page.asp?Section=7494 External link]) in the municipalities of [[Kuusamo]] and [[Salla]], Oulanka National Park, [[Lapland, Finland|Lapland]] *The Peuran polku Trail: ({{convert|115|km}}, [https://web.archive.org/web/20061007161511/http://www.luontoon.fi/page.asp?Section=5319 External link]) in the municipalities of Kivijärvi, Kinnula, Perho, Lestijärvi and Reisjärvi in [[Central Finland]], [[Central Ostrobothnia]], and [[Northern Ostrobothnia]]—a part of [[European walking route E6]]
===France=== * [[GR footpath#France: Grande Randonnée|Sentier de Grande Randonnée (GR)]] * [[Haute Randonnée Pyrénéenne]] (HRP): High Pyrenees Trail, along the border with Spain. * The [[Tour du Lot]]: a circuit of over {{convert|500|km}} around the Department of the Lot's periphery. * [[Metropolitan Trail|Sentier Métropolitain]]: urban and suburban hiking routes, that allow their users to discover a metropolitan territory in several days of hiking.
===Germany=== * Barbarossaweg: Korbach to Kyffhäuserdenkmal ({{convert|332|km}}) * Bergischer Weg: Essen to Königswinter ({{convert|137|km}}) * [[Birkenhainer Strasse]]: Hanau to Gemünden am Main ({{convert|71|km}}) * Bonifatiusweg: Mainz to Fulda ({{convert|180|km}}) * Christine-Koch-Weg: Menden to Bad Laasphe ({{convert|123|km}}) * [[Eselsweg]]: Schlüchtern to Großheubach ({{convert|111|km}}) *[[König-Ludwig-Weg]]: Berg am Starnberger See to Füssen ({{convert|120|km}}) *[[Maximiliansweg]]: Lindau to Berchtesgaden ({{convert|350|km}}) *[[Moselhöhenweg]]: Trier to Koblenz *[[Pandurensteig]]: Waldmuenchen to Passau *[[Rennsteig]]: Hörsel to Blankenstein/Saale through the Thuringian Forest ({{convert|169|km}}) *[[Rheinburgenweg Trail]]: Bingen to Koblenz to Rüdesheim am Rhein (''c''.{{convert|200|km}}) *[[Rheinhöhenweg Trail]]: Bonn to Alsheim/Wiesbaden ({{convert|530|km}}) *[[Rheinsteig]]: Bonn to Wiesbaden ({{convert|320|km}}) *[[Westweg]] (Black Forest western ridgeway): Pforzheim to Basel ({{convert|279|km}}) *[[Mittelweg]] (Black Forest central ridgeway): Pforzheim to Waldshut ({{convert|233|km}}) *[[Ostweg]] (Black Forest eastern ridgeway): Pforzheim to Schaffhausen ({{convert|238|km}}) *[[Black Forest North Perimeter Way]]: Mühlacker to Karlsruhe ({{convert|71|km}}) * [[Freiburg-Lake Constance Black Forest Trail]]: Freiburg to Konstanz ({{convert|183|km}}) *[[Saar-Hunsrück-Steig]]: Trier to Saarschleife in Mettlach or Idar-Oberstein 9 ({{convert|180|km}})

**[http://www.lakecomo.it/en/excursions_and_trekking/il_sentiero_delle_4_valli ''Il Sentiero delle 4 Valli''] The "Four Valleys Path" between Lake Como and [[Lake Lugano]] **''[[La Via dei Monti === Poland === *[[Główny Szlak Sudecki]] (Main Sudety Trail): {{convert|440|km}} in [[Sudetes]] Mountains from [[Świeradów Zdrój]] to [[Prudnik]] *[[Main Beskid Trail|Główny Szlak Beskidzki]] (Main Beskidy Trail): {{convert|519|km}} in [[Beskids]] Mountains, from [[Wołosate]] to [[Ustroń]],<ref>[http://www.czerwonyszlak.republika.pl/opis_trasy.htm Główny Szlak Beskidzki - opis trasy]</ref> the longest public trail in Poland *[[Polish - Czech Friendship Trail]]: trail along the Polish and Czech border in [[Sudetes]]

===Spain=== * [[Way of St. James]] (Spanish: El Camino de Santiago) * [[Route of the Monasteries of Valencia]] (Spanish: Ruta de los Monasterios de Valencia) * [[Grande Randonnée]] 7 ([[GR 7 (Spain)|GR 7]]): From [[Tarifa]] to the mountain cabin of Fontferrera, part of the [[European walking route E4|E4]] route. * [[Grande Randonnée]] 11 ([[GR 11 (Spain)|GR 11]]): [[Pyrenees]] Trail, staying within Spain. * [[Haute Randonnée Pyrénéenne]] (HRP): High Pyrenees Trail, along the border with France. * [http://www.caminodosfaros.com O Camiño dos Faros (The Lighthouse Way)] : 200 km (124 mi) along the coastline from Malpica to Fisterra, in Galicia (Spain)
===Sweden=== *[[Kungsleden]], {{convert|425|km}} from the northern extremity of the country *[http://www.sormlandsleden.se/default.aspx Sörmlandsleden] {{convert|1000|km}} of winding paths through the county of Sörmland. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100920070341/http://www.nordwinde.de/InfoBohus_eng.html Bohusleden] {{convert|360|km}} past at Göteborg, Uddevalla, Munkedal and ends finally in Strömstad * [[Ingegerdsleden]], 110 kilometres (68 mi), pilgrimage route in county of [[Uppland]] between [[Uppsala Cathedral]] and [[Stockholm Cathedral]]. * [[Skåneleden]], more than {{convert|1000|km}} long path through the province of [[Scania]]. Part of the [[North Sea Trail]].

==South America==
===Argentina=== *[[Los Glaciares]] ** Various options to Laguna Torre, Cerro FitzRoy, or even out onto the [[Southern Patagonian Ice Field]] *[[Huella Andina]] ** 570 kilometers from [[Alumine Lake]] to [[Baggilt lake]]<ref>http://huellaandina.desarrolloturistico.gov.ar/</ref>
===Bolivia=== *[[Cordillera Real (Bolivia)]] ** 106 kilometres (66 mi) 7-day Illampu Circuit
===Brazil=== *[[Serra dos Órgãos]] ** {{convert|36|km}} between Petrópolis and Teresópolis (medium to hard trail) *[[Transcarioca Trail]] ** {{convert|183|km}} in Rio de Janeiro city (medium to hard trail) <ref>http://trilhatranscarioca.com.br/</ref> *[[Transmantiqueira Trail]] ** {{convert|700|km}} between Extrema and Aiuruoca (very hard trail) <ref>https://www.facebook.com/trilhatransmantiqueira/</ref> *[[Caminho da Fe]] ** {{convert|538| km}}. There are 3 different starting points: *** from Sao Carlos to [[Aparecida]] *** or from Cravinhos to Aparecida *** or from Mococa to Aparecida
===Chile=== *Central Chile and Patagonia **3,000 kilometers (1,850 mi) [[Hiking in Chile#Greater Patagonian Trail|Greater Patagonian Trail]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dudeck|first1=Jan|title=Greater Patagonian Trail|url=http://www.wikiexplora.com/index.php/Greater_Patagonian_Trail|website=wikiexplora|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> from the capital Santiago de Chile to the Southern Patagonian Ice Field. *Magallanes **118 kilometers. Full circuit of [[Torres del Paine]], including Valle del Francés and access to the base of Torres del Paine.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meneses|first1=Patricia|title=Trekking Torres del Paine|url=http://www.wikiexplora.com/index.php/Trekking_Torres_del_Paine|website=Wikiexplora|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> **Dientes de Navarino Circuit ~53km. 3 - 7 days. Starts out of Puerto Williams. Access from mainland Chile by ferry from Punta Areas, plane or from Ushuaia. http://rutas.bienes.cl/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/01.pdf
===Peru=== *[[Cordillera Blanca]] and [[Huayhuash mountain range|Huayhuash]] mountain range near [[Huaráz]] **30 kilometers (19 mi) 10- to 14-day trek on the Huayhuash Circuit **52 kilometers (33 mi) 3- to 4-day "W" Circuit Santa Cruz trek **94 kilometers (59 mi) 6- to 10-day Alpamayo Circuit, full "O" Circuit *[[Sacred Valley]] & [[Vilcanota mountain range]] near [[Cuzco]] **88 kilometers (55 mi) for the longest Mollepata variant of the [[Inca trail]], with options for a single day to more than six days, all ending at [[Machu Picchu]] **32 kilometers (20 mi) Cachora to [[Choquequirao]] trek **80 kilometers (50 mi) 5- to 6-day trek on Ausangate Circuit *[[Colca Canyon]] near [[Arequipa]] **60 kilometers (37 mi) 5-day trek around Canyon or other single-day and multi-day hikes

{{refimprove|date=March 2018}} This is a list of [[natural history museum]]s, also known as museums of natural history, i.e. [[museum]]s whose exhibits focus on the subject of [[natural history]], including such topics as [[animal]]s, [[plants]], [[ecosystems]], [[geology]], [[paleontology]], and [[climatology]].
Some museums feature natural-history collections in addition to other collections, such as ones related to history, art and science. In addition, [[nature center]]s often include natural-history exhibits.
{{TOC right}}

{{DEFAULTSORT:Natural History Museums}} [[Category:Geology museums|*]] [[Category:Lists of museums|National History]] [[Category:Natural history museums|*]] [[Category:Nature-related lists]] [[Category:Science museums|*]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} Knowledge of the '''location of Earth''' has been shaped by 400 years of telescopic observations, and has expanded radically in the last century. Initially, Earth was believed to be the [[Geocentric model|center of the Universe]], which consisted only of those planets visible with the [[classical planet|naked eye]] and an outlying sphere of [[fixed stars]].{{cite book |first=Thomas S. |last=Kuhn |title=The Copernican Revolution |pages=5–20 |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |date=1957 |isbn=978-0-674-17103-9}} After the acceptance of the [[heliocentric model]] in the 17th century, observations by [[William Herschel]] and others showed that the Sun lay within a vast, disc-shaped [[galaxy]] of stars.{{cite web|title=1781: William Herschel Reveals the Shape of our Galaxy|url=http://cosmology.carnegiescience.edu/timeline/1781|publisher=[[Carnegie Institution for Science]]|accessdate=19 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140326182039/http://cosmology.carnegiescience.edu/timeline/1781|archivedate=26 March 2014|df=dmy-all}} By the 20th century, observations of [[spiral nebula]]e revealed that our galaxy was one of billions in an [[expanding universe]],{{cite web|title=The Spiral Nebulae and the Great Debate|publisher=[[Eberly College of Science]]|url=https://www.e-education.psu.edu/astro801/content/l9_p2.html|accessdate=22 April 2015}}{{cite web|title=1929: Edwin Hubble Discovers the Universe is Expanding|publisher=Carnegie Institution for Science|url=https://cosmology.carnegiescience.edu/timeline/1929|accessdate=22 April 2015}} grouped into clusters and [[supercluster]]s. By the end of the 20th century, the [[large-scale structure of the cosmos|overall structure]] of the visible universe was becoming clearer, with superclusters forming into a vast web of [[galactic filament|filaments]] and [[Void (astronomy)|voids]].{{cite web|title=1989: Margaret Geller and John Huchra Map the Universe|publisher=[[Carnegie Institution for Science]]|url=https://cosmology.carnegiescience.edu/timeline/1989|accessdate=22 April 2015}} Superclusters, filaments and voids are the largest coherent structures in the Universe that we can observe.{{cite web|title=Structure of the Universe|author= Villanueva, John Carl |publisher=[[Universe Today]]|year=2009|url=http://www.universetoday.com/37360/structure-of-the-universe/|accessdate=22 April 2015}} At still larger scales (over 1000 [[megaparsec]]s{{efn|name=parsec|A parsec (pc) is the distance at which a star's [[parallax]] as viewed from Earth is equal to one [[second of arc]], equal to roughly 206,000 AU or 3.0857×1013 km. One [[megaparsec]] (Mpc) is equivalent to one million [[parsec]]s.}}) the Universe becomes homogeneous meaning that all its parts have on average the same density, composition and structure.{{cite book |title=The Extravagant Universe: Exploding Stars, Dark Energy and the Accelerating Cosmos |author=Kirshner, Robert P. |url=https://books.google.com/?id=qQ_mV2prqNYC&pg=PA71 |page=71 |isbn=978-0-691-05862-7 |date=2002 |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]}} Since there is believed to be no "center" or "edge" of the Universe, there is no particular reference point with which to plot the overall location of the Earth in the universe.{{cite book |title=The Little Book of Time |author1=Mainzer, Klaus |author2=Eisinger, J. |isbn=978-0-387-95288-8 |date=2002 |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wX111YnexSUC&pg=PA55|page=55}} Because the [[observable universe]] is defined as that region of the Universe visible to terrestrial observers, Earth is, by definition, the center of Earth's observable universe.{{cite book|author1=Liddle, Andrew R. |author2=Lyth, David Hilary |title=Cosmological inflation and large-scale structure|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XmWauPZSovMC&pg=PA24|date= 2000|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=978-0-521-57598-0|pages=24–}} Reference can be made to the Earth's position with respect to specific structures, which exist at various scales. It is still undetermined whether the Universe is [[Infinity|infinite]]. There have been numerous hypotheses that our universe may be only one such example within a higher [[multiverse]]; however, no direct evidence of any sort of multiverse has ever been observed, and some have argued that the hypothesis is not [[falsifiable]].{{cite web|title=5 Reasons We May Live in a Multiverse |url=http://www.space.com/18811-multiple-universes-5-theories.html |author= Moskowitz, Clara|publisher=space.com|year=2012|accessdate=29 April 2015}}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1080/00033790903047725| title = Contemporary History of Cosmology and the Controversy over the Multiverse| journal = Annals of Science| volume = 66| issue = 4| pages = 529–551| year = 2009| last1 = Kragh | first1 = H. }} [[File:Location of Earth (1x9-English Annot-small).png|thumb|200px|right|A diagram of our location in the [[observable universe]].]] {|class="wikitable" |- !Feature || Diameter || Notes || Sources |- |'''[[Earth]]''' || 12,756.2 km
(equatorial) || Measurement comprises just the solid part of the Earth; there is no agreed upper boundary for [[Earth's atmosphere]].
The [[geocorona]], a layer of UV-luminescent hydrogen atoms, lies at 100,000 km.
The [[Kármán line]], defined as the boundary of space [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale|for astronautics]], lies at 100 km. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|title=Selected Astronomical Constants, 2011|work=The Astronomical Almanac|url=http://asa.usno.navy.mil/SecK/2011/Astronomical_Constants_2011.txt|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130826043456/http://asa.usno.navy.mil/SecK/2011/Astronomical_Constants_2011.txt|archivedate=26 August 2013|accessdate=25 February 2011}}[[World Geodetic System]] (''WGS-84''). [http://earth-info.nga.mil/GandG/wgs84/ Available online] from [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] Retrieved 27 April 2015.{{cite web|title=Exosphere – overview|publisher=University Corporation for Atmospheric Research|year=2011|url=http://scied.ucar.edu/shortcontent/exosphere-overview|accessdate=28 April 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.org/icare-records/100km-altitude-boundary-for-astronautics|title=The 100 km Boundary for Astronautics|author=S. Sanz Fernández de Córdoba|publisher=[[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]]|date=2004-06-24|accessdate=2014-05-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/618QHms8h?url=http://www.fai.org/astronautics/100km.asp|archivedate=22 August 2011|df=dmy-all}} |- |[[Orbit of the Moon]] ||768,210 km{{efn|name=axes|[[semi-major axis|Semi-major]] and [[semi-minor axis|semi-minor axes]].}} || The average diameter of the orbit of the Moon relative to the Earth. || style="text-align:center;" | [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/moonfact.html NASA Moon Factsheet] and [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Moon&Display=Facts NASA Solar System Exploration Moon Factsheet] ''[[NASA]]'' Retrieved on 17 November 2008 |- |[[Geospace]] ||6,363,000–12,663,000 km
(110–210 Earth radii) || The space dominated by [[Earth's magnetic field]] and its [[magnetotail]], shaped by the [[solar wind]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{citation | last1=Koskinen | first1=Hannu | date=2010 | title=Physics of Space Storms: From the Surface of the Sun to the Earth | series=Environmental Sciences Series | publisher=Springer | isbn=978-3-642-00310-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cO0nwfhXVjUC&pg=PA32}} |- |[[Earth's orbit]] ||299.2 million km{{efn|name=axes}}
2 [[Astronomical unit|AU]]{{efn|name=au|1 AU or [[astronomical unit]] is the distance between the Earth and the Sun, or 150 million km. Earth's orbital diameter is twice its orbital radius, or 2 AU.}}|| The average diameter of the orbit of the Earth relative to the Sun.
Encompasses the [[Sun]], [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]] and [[Venus]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/earthfact.html |title=Earth Fact Sheet |publisher=[[NASA]] |access-date=17 November 2008}} and {{cite web |url=http://sse.jpl.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Earth&Display=Facts&System=Metric |website=Solar System Exploration |title=Earth: Facts & Figures |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090827003435/http://sse.jpl.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Earth&Display=Facts&System=Metric |archive-date=27 August 2009 |publisher=[[NASA]] |access-date=17 November 2008}} |- |[[Inner Solar System]] || ~6.54 AU || Encompasses the Sun, the [[inner planets]] (Mercury, Venus, Earth, [[Mars]]) and the [[asteroid belt]].
Cited distance is the 2:1 [[orbital resonance|resonance]] with Jupiter, which marks the outer limit of the asteroid belt. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal |author1=Petit, J.-M. |author2=Morbidelli, A. |author3=Chambers, J. | title=The Primordial Excitation and Clearing of the Asteroid Belt | journal=[[Icarus (journal)|Icarus]] | date=2001 | volume=153 | issue=2 | pages=338–347 | url=http://www.gps.caltech.edu/classes/ge133/reading/asteroids.pdf | format=PDF | accessdate=22 March 2007 | doi = 10.1006/icar.2001.6702 | bibcode=2001Icar..153..338P }}{{cite journal|title= Asteroids in the 2 : 1 resonance with Jupiter: dynamics and size distribution|author1=Roig, F. |author2=Nesvorný, D. |author3= Ferraz-Mello, S. |last-author-amp=yes |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=335|issue=2|pages=417–431|year=2002|bibcode = 2002MNRAS.335..417R |doi = 10.1046/j.1365-8711.2002.05635.x }}{{cite journal|title=Yarkovsky origin of the unstable asteroids in the 2/1 mean motionresonance with Jupiter| journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=359| issue=4|pages=1437–1455|year=2005|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08995.x|bibcode=2005MNRAS.359.1437B| last1=Brož| first1=M| last2=Vokrouhlický| first2=D| last3=Roig| first3=F| last4=Nesvorný| first4=D| last5=Bottke| first5=W. F| last6=Morbidelli| first6=A}} |- |[[Outer Solar System]] || 60.14 AU || Includes the [[outer planets]] ([[Jupiter]], [[Saturn]], [[Uranus]], [[Neptune]]).
Cited distance is the orbital diameter of Neptune. || style="text-align:center;" | [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/neptunefact.html NASA Neptune factsheet] and [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Neptune&Display=Facts NASA Solar System Exploration Neptune Factsheet] ''NASA'' Retrieved on 17 November 2008 |- |[[Kuiper belt]] || ~96 AU || Belt of icy objects surrounding the [[outer Solar System]]. Encompasses the [[dwarf planet]]s [[Pluto]], [[Haumea (dwarf planet)|Haumea]] and [[Makemake (dwarf planet)|Makemake]].
Cited distance is the 2:1 [[orbital resonance|resonance]] with Neptune, generally regarded as the inner edge of the main Kuiper belt. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal |title=Thermal Evolution and Differentiation of Edgeworth–Kuiper Belt Objects |journal=[[The Astronomical Journal]] |doi= 10.1086/320385 |volume=121 |issue= 5 |pages=2792–2799 |date=2001 |bibcode=2001AJ....121.2792D|last1=De Sanctis |first1=M. C |last2=Capria |first2=M. T |last3=Coradini |first3=A }} |- |[[Heliosphere]] || 160 AU|| Maximum extent of the [[solar wind]] and the [[interplanetary medium]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|title=Cassini's Big Sky: The View from the Center of Our Solar System |author=NASA/JPL |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/features.cfm?feature=2370&msource=F20091119&tr=y&auid=5615216 |date=2009 |accessdate=20 December 2009}}{{cite journal |date=2000 |author=Fahr, H. J. |author2=Kausch, T. |author3=Scherer, H. |title=A 5-fluid hydrodynamic approach to model the Solar System-interstellar medium interaction |journal=[[Astronomy & Astrophysics]] |volume=357 |pages=268 |url=http://aa.springer.de/papers/0357001/2300268.pdf |format=PDF |bibcode=2000A&A...357..268F }} See Figures 1 and 2. |- |[[Scattered disc]] || 195.3 AU|| Region of sparsely scattered icy objects surrounding the Kuiper belt. Encompasses the dwarf planet [[Eris (dwarf planet)|Eris]].
Cited distance is derived by doubling the [[aphelion]] of Eris, the farthest known scattered disc object.
As of now, Eris's aphelion marks the farthest known point in the scattered disc. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web |type=2008-10-04 last obs |title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 136199 Eris (2003 UB313) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=Eris |accessdate=21 January 2009}} |- |[[Oort cloud]] || 100,000–200,000 AU
0.613–1.23 [[parsec|pc]]{{efn|name=parsec}} || Spherical shell of over a trillion (1012) [[comet]]s. Existence is currently hypothetical, but inferred from the orbits of [[long-period comet]]s. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite arXiv |title=Origin and dynamical evolution of comets and their reservoir |author=Morbidelli, Alessandro |eprint=astro-ph/0512256 |date=2005 }} |- |'''[[Solar System]]''' || 1.23 pc || The Sun and its [[planetary system]]. Cited diameter is that of the Sun's [[Hill sphere]]; the region of its gravitational influence. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite book|last=Littmann|first=Mark|title=Planets Beyond: Discovering the Outer Solar System|date=2004|pages=162–163|publisher=Courier Dover Publications|isbn=978-0-486-43602-9}} |- |[[Local Interstellar Cloud]] || 9.2 pc || [[Interstellar cloud]] of gas through which the Sun and a number of other stars are currently travelling. || style="text-align:center;" | Mark Anderson, "Don't stop till you get to the Fluff", ''[[New Scientist]]'' no. 2585, 6 January 2007, pp. 26–30 |- |[[Local Bubble]] || 2.82–250 pc || Cavity in the [[interstellar medium]] in which the Sun and a number of other stars are currently travelling.
Caused by a past [[supernova]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal|title=Mapping the Countours of the Local Bubble|author=Seifr, D.M. |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics|volume=346|date=1999|pages=785–797|bibcode= 1999A&A...346..785S}}{{cite web|title=Evidence for Supernovas Near Earth|url=https://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/26aug_localbubble/|author=Phillips, Tony |publisher=NASA|year=2014|accessdate=2015-04-30}} |- |[[Gould Belt]] || 1,000 pc || Ring of young stars through which the Sun is currently travelling.|| style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal|title=Young isolated neutron stars from the Gould Belt |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics| volume=406|issue=1|pages=111–117|date=2003|doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20030680|bibcode=2003A&A...406..111P|arxiv = astro-ph/0304141 |last1=Popov|first1=S. B|last2=Colpi|first2=M|last3=Prokhorov|first3=M. E|last4=Treves|first4=A|last5=Turolla|first5=R}} |- |[[Orion Arm]]|| 3000 pc
(length)||The [[spiral arm]] of the Milky Way Galaxy through which the Sun is currently travelling.
|| style="text-align:center;" | |- |[[Galactic year|Orbit of the Solar System]] || 17,200 pc|| The average diameter of the orbit of the Solar System relative to the [[Galactic Center]].
The Sun's orbital radius is roughly 8,600 parsecs, or slightly over half way to the galactic edge.
One orbital period of the Solar System lasts between 225 and 250 million years. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal |first1=F. |last=Eisenhauer |first2=R. |last2=Schoedel |first3=R. |last3=Genzel |first4=T. |last4=Ott |first5=M. |last5=Tecza |first6= R. |last6=Abuter |first7=A. |last7=Eckart |first8=T. |last8=Alexander |title=A Geometric Determination of the Distance to the Galactic Center |journal=[[Astrophysical Journal]] |volume=597 |issue=2 |pages=L121–L124 |date=2003 |doi=10.1086/380188 |bibcode=2003ApJ...597L.121E |arxiv = astro-ph/0306220 }}{{cite web|url=http://hypertextbook.com/facts/2002/StacyLeong.shtml|work=The Physics Factbook|last=Leong|first=Stacy|date=2002|title=Period of the Sun's Orbit around the Galaxy (Cosmic Year)}} |- |'''[[Milky Way Galaxy]]''' || 30,000 pc || Our home [[galaxy]], composed of 200 billion to 400 billion stars and filled with the [[interstellar medium]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|publisher=NASA | last = Christian | first = Eric | last2 = Samar | first2 = Safi-Harb | title = How large is the Milky Way? | url=http://imagine.gsfc.nasa.gov/docs/ask_astro/answers/980317b.html | accessdate = 28 November 2007 }}{{cite web |author1=Frommert, H. |author2=Kronberg, C. | date =25 August 2005 | url =http://messier.seds.org/more/mw.html | title =The Milky Way Galaxy | publisher =[[SEDS]] | accessdate = 9 May 2007 }} |- |[[Milky Way subgroup]] || 840,500 pc || The Milky Way and those satellite [[dwarf galaxies]] gravitationally bound to it.
Examples include the [[Sagittarius Dwarf Elliptical Galaxy|Sagittarius Dwarf]], the [[Ursa Minor Dwarf]] and the [[Canis Major Dwarf]].
Cited distance is the orbital diameter of the [[Leo T Dwarf]] galaxy, the most distant galaxy in the Milky Way subgroup. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal|last=Irwin|first=V.|author2=Belokurov, V.|author3=Evans, N. W.|display-authors=etal|title=Discovery of an Unusual Dwarf Galaxy in the Outskirts of the Milky Way|date=2007|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=656|issue=1|pages=L13–L16|doi=10.1086/512183|bibcode=2007ApJ...656L..13I|arxiv=astro-ph/0701154 }} |- |[[Local Group]] ||3 [[megaparsec|Mpc]]{{efn|name=parsec}}|| [[Galaxy groups and clusters|Group]] of at least 54 galaxies of which the Milky Way is a part.
Dominated by [[Andromeda Galaxy|Andromeda]] (the largest), the Milky Way and [[Triangulum Galaxy|Triangulum]]; the remainder are [[dwarf galaxies]].|| style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|title=The Local Group of Galaxies|url=http://messier.seds.org/more/local.html|publisher=Students for the Exploration and Development of Space|work=University of Arizona|accessdate=2 October 2009}} |- |[[Local Sheet]] ||7 Mpc|| Group of galaxies including the Local Group moving at the same relative velocity towards the [[Virgo Cluster]] and away from the [[Local Void]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal | last1=Tully | first=R. Brent | last2=Shaya | first2=Edward J. | last3=Karachentsev | first3=Igor D. | last4=Courtois | first4=Hélène M. | last5=Kocevski | first5=Dale D. | last6=Rizzi | first6=Luca | last7=Peel | first7=Alan | title=Our Peculiar Motion Away from the Local Void | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | volume=676 | issue=1 | pages=184–205 |date=March 2008 | doi=10.1086/527428 | arxiv=0705.4139 | bibcode=2008ApJ...676..184T }}{{cite book | last1=Tully | first1=R. Brent | chapter=The Local Void is Really Empty | title=Dark Galaxies and Lost Baryons, Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union, IAU Symposium | journal=Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union | volume=244 | pages=146–151 |date=May 2008 | doi=10.1017/S1743921307013932 | bibcode=2008IAUS..244..146T | arxiv=0708.0864 }} |- |[[Virgo Supercluster]] || 30 Mpc || The [[supercluster]] of which the Local Group is a part.
It comprises roughly 100 [[galaxy groups and clusters]], centred on the [[Virgo Cluster]].
The Local Group is located on the outer edge of the Virgo Supercluster. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal|title=The Local Supercluster|author=Tully, R. Brent |journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=257|pages=389–422|year=1982|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-iarticle_query?1982ApJ...257..389T&data_type=PDF_HIGH&whole_paper=YES&type=PRINTER&filetype=.pdf|accessdate=27 April 2015 |bibcode = 1982ApJ...257..389T |doi = 10.1086/159999 }}{{cite web|title=Galaxies, Clusters, and Superclusters|publisher=NOVA Online|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/universe/tour_ggs.html|accessdate=27 April 2015}} |- |[[Laniakea Supercluster|Laniakea]] || 160 Mpc || A group connected with the [[supercluster]]s of which the Local Group is a part.
Comprises roughly 300 to 500 [[galaxy groups and clusters]], centred on the [[Great Attractor]] in the [[Hydra-Centaurus Supercluster]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite news |work= National Radio Astronomy Observatory |publisher= ScienceDaily |date= 3 September 2014 |url= https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/09/140903133319.htm |title= Newly identified galactic supercluster is home to the Milky Way }}{{cite web |work= Reuters |publisher= ScienceDaily |date= 3 September 2014 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/03/us-space-galaxies-idUSKBN0GY2C820140903|author= Klotz, Irene |title= New map shows Milky Way lives in Laniakea galaxy complex }}{{cite news |publisher= ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' |url=http://www.nature.com/news/earth-s-new-address-solar-system-milky-way-laniakea-1.15819|title= Earth's new address: 'Solar System, Milky Way, Laniakea' |author= Gibney, Elizabeth |date= 3 September 2014 |doi= 10.1038/nature.2014.15819 }}{{cite news |url= http://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/laniakea-home-supercluster-09032014/ |title= Laniakea: Our Home Supercluster |author= Carlisle, Camille M. |date= 3 September 2014 |publisher= Sky and Telescope }} |- |[[Observable universe]] || 28,500 Mpc || [[Observable universe|At least 2 trillion galaxies in the observable universe]], arranged in millions of superclusters, [[galactic filament]]s, and [[void (astronomy)|voids]], creating a [[cosmic web|foam-like superstructure]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web | last = Mackie | first = Glen | date=1 February 2002 | url = http://astronomy.swin.edu.au/~gmackie/billions.html | title = To see the Universe in a Grain of Taranaki Sand | publisher = Swinburne University | accessdate = 20 December 2006 }}{{cite web | last = Lineweaver | first = Charles |author2=Davis, Tamara M. | date = 2005 | url = http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=misconceptions-about-the-2005-03&page=5 | title = Misconceptions about the Big Bang | publisher = [[Scientific American]] | accessdate = 6 November 2008}}{{Cite journal|last=Conselice|first=Christopher J.|last2=Wilkinson|first2=Aaron|last3=Duncan|first3=Kenneth|last4=Mortlock|first4=Alice|date=2016-10-13|title=The Evolution of Galaxy Number Density at z < 8 and its Implications|arxiv=1607.03909|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=830|issue=2|pages=83|doi=10.3847/0004-637X/830/2/83|issn=1538-4357|bibcode=2016ApJ...830...83C}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/18/science/two-trillion-galaxies-at-the-very-least.html|title=Two Trillion Galaxies, at the Very Least|date=2016-10-17|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-13}} |- |'''[[Universe]]''' || Minimum 28,500 Mpc
possibly infinite || Beyond the observable universe lie the unobservable regions [[Particle horizon|from which no light has reached the Earth yet]].
No information is available, as light is the fastest travelling medium of information.
However, [[uniformitarianism]] argues that the Universe is likely to contain more galaxies in the same foam-like superstructure. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal |last1=Margalef-Bentabol |first1=Berta |last2=Margalef-Bentabol |first2=Juan |last3=Cepa |first3=Jordi |title=Evolution of the cosmological horizons in a universe with countably infinitely many state equations |journal=Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics |date=February 2013 |volume=2013 |series=015 |issue=2 |doi=10.1088/1475-7516/2013/02/015 |arxiv=1302.2186|bibcode = 2013JCAP...02..015M|pages=015}} |- |} ==See also== *[[Orders of magnitude (length)]] *''[[Cosmic View]]'' *''[[Cosmic Zoom]]'' *''[[Pale Blue Dot]]'' *[[Powers of Ten (film)|''Powers of Ten'' (film)]] *''[[Galaxy Song]]'' ==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Earth's location}} {{Earth}} {{Orders of magnitude}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Earth's Location In The Universe}} [[Category:Earth|Location in the Universe]] [[Category:Physical universe]]

revision.text:
[[File:McLeod gauge 01.jpg|right|thumb|A glass McLeod gauge, drained of mercury]]
A '''McLeod gauge''' is a scientific instrument used to measure very low [[pressure]]s, down to 10<sup>−6</sup> [[Torr]]. It was invented in 1874 by [[Herbert McLeod]] (1841–1923).<ref name=PhilSoc>{{cite journal |first=Herbert |last=McLeod |journal=Philosophical Magazine |volume=xlviii |date=1874 |pages=110–113 |title=Apparatus for measurement of low pressures of gas}}</ref> McLeod gauges were once commonly found attached to equipment that operates under [[vacuum]], such as a [[freeze drying|lyophilizer]]. Today, however, these gauges have largely been replaced by electronic vacuum gauges.
The design of a McLeod gauge is somewhat similar to that of a [[Pressure measurement#Liquid column|mercury-column manometer]]. Typically it is filled with [[Mercury (element)|mercury]]. If used incorrectly, this mercury can escape and contaminate the vacuum system attached to the gauge.
[[File:McLeod manometer.png|left|thumb|100px|McLeod manometer symbol according to [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] 3753-1977 (E)]] McLeod gauges operate by taking in a sample volume of gas from a vacuum chamber, then compressing it by tilting and infilling with mercury. The pressure in this smaller volume is then measured by a mercury manometer, and knowing the compression ratio (the ratio of the initial and final volumes), the pressure of the original vacuum can be determined by applying [[Boyle's law]].
This method is fairly accurate for non-condensible gases, such as oxygen and nitrogen. However, condensible gases, such as water vapour, ammonia, carbon dioxide, and pump-oil vapors may be in gaseous form in the low pressure of the vacuum chamber, but will condense when compressed by the McLeod gauge. The result is an erroneous reading, showing a pressure much lower than actually present. A [[cold trap]] may be used in conjunction with a McLeod gauge to condense these vapors before they enter the gauge.
The McLeod gauge has the advantage that it is simple to use and that its calibration is nearly the same for all non-condensable gases. The device can be manually operated and the scale read visually, or the process can be automated in various ways. For example, a small electric motor can periodically rotate the assembly to collect a gas sample. If a fine platinum wire is in the capillary tube, its resistance indicates the height of the mercury column around it.
Modern electronic [[vacuum gauge]]s are simpler to use, less fragile, and do not present a mercury hazard, but their reading is highly dependent on the chemical nature of the gas being measured, and their calibration is unstable. For this reason, McLeod gauges continue to be used as a calibration standard for electronic gauges.
==See also== * [[Penning gauge]] * [[Pirani gauge]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * http://physics.kenyon.edu/EarlyApparatus/Pneumatics/McLeod_Gauge/McLeod_Gauge.html * https://web.archive.org/web/20060504124236/http://www.tau.ac.il/~phchlab/experiments/vacuum/Techniques_of_high_vacuum/Vacuum5.html

revision.text:
{{broader|Natural environment}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Biodiversity}} A '''natural landscape''' is the original landscape that exists before it is acted upon by human culture.<ref group = note>"The area prior to the introduction of man 's activity is represented by one body of morphologic facts. The forms that man has introduced are another set. We may call the former, with reference to man, the original, natural landscape. In its entirety it no longer exists in many parts of the world, but its reconstruction and understanding are the first part of formal morphonology." Carl O. Sauer, "The Morphology of Landscape". ''University of California Publications in Geography'', vol. 2, No. 2, 12 October 1925, p. 37.[https://archive.org/stream/universityofc02univ/universityofc02univ_djvu.txt]</ref> The natural landscape and the [[cultural landscape]] are separate parts of the [[landscape]].<ref group = note>"The cultural landscape is fashioned from a natural landscape by a culture group. Culture is the agent, the natural area is the medium, the cultural landscape the result." Carl O. Sauer, "The Morphology of Landscape", p. 46.</ref> However, in the twenty-first century landscapes that are totally untouched by human activity no longer exist, so that reference is sometimes now made to degrees of naturalness within a landscape.<ref group = note>The [[European Environment Agency]]'s planned forest naturalness index is an example of an attempt to define one type of natural landscape in Europe. The Agency lists forests in three categories: (1) [[Plantations]]; (2) Semi-natural; and (3) Naturally dynamic. The latter are "forests whose structure, composition and function have been shaped by natural dynamics without substantial [[Human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] influence over a long period of time".</ref>
In ''[[Silent Spring]]'' (1962) [[Rachel Carson]] describes a roadside verge as it used to look: "Along the roads, laurel, viburnum and alder, great ferns and wildflowers delighted the traveler’s eye through much of the year" and then how it looks now following the use of [[herbicide]]s: "The roadsides, once so attractive, were now lined with browned and withered vegetation as though swept by fire".<ref>Cambridge, Mass.: Riverside Press, 1962, p. 1.</ref> Even though the landscape before it is sprayed is biologically degraded, and may well contains alien species, the concept of what might constitute a natural landscape can still be deduced from the context.
The phrase "natural landscape" was first used in connection with [[landscape painting]], and [[landscape gardening]], to contrast a formal style with a more natural one, closer to nature. [[Alexander von Humboldt]] (1769 – 1859) was to further conceptualize this into the idea of a natural landscape ''separate'' from the [[cultural landscape]]. Then in 1908 [[geographer]] [[Otto Schlüter]] developed the terms original landscape (''Urlandschaft'') and its opposite cultural landscape (''Kulturlandschaft'') in an attempt to give the science of geography a subject matter that was different from the other sciences. An early use of the actual phrase "natural landscape" by a [[geographer]] can be found in [[Carl O. Sauer]]'s paper "The Morphology of Landscape" (1925).<ref>[[Carl O. Sauer]], "The Morphology of Landscape". ''University of California Publications in Geography'' 2 (2), pp. 19-53.</ref>
==Origins of the term== The concept of a natural landscape was first developed in connection with [[landscape painting]], though the actual term itself was first used in relation to [[landscape gardening]]. In both cases it was used to contrast a formal style with a more natural one, that is closer to nature. Chunglin Kwa suggests, "that a seventeenth-century or early-eighteenth-century person could experience natural scenery ‘just like on a painting,’ and so, with or without the use of the word itself, designate it as a landscape."<ref>Chunglin Kwa, "Alexander von Humboldt's invention of the natural landscape", ''The European Legacy'', Vol. 10, No. 2, pp. 149-162, 2005</ref> With regard to landscape gardening John Aikin, commented in 1794: "Whatever, therefore, there be of ''novelty'' in the singular scenery of an artificial garden, it is soon exhausted, whereas the infinite diversity of a natural landscape presents an inexhaustible flore of new forms".<ref>J. Aikin, M.D., ''Letters from a Father to His Son, on Various Topics, Relative to Literature and the Conduct of Life. Written in the Years 1792 and 1793'', (Philadelphia: Samuel Harrison Smith), p. 148.</ref> Writing in 1844 the prominent American landscape gardener [[Andrew Jackson Downing]] comments: "straight canals, round or oblong pieces of water, and all the regular forms of the geometric mode ... would evidently be in violent opposition to the whole character and expression of natural landscape".<ref>''A Treatise on the Theory and Practice of Landscape Gardening Adapted to North America''.</ref>
In his extensive travels in South America, [[Alexander von Humboldt]] became the first to conceptualize a natural landscape separate from the cultural landscape, though he does not actually use these terms.<ref>https://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext05/qnct310.txt</ref><ref>[http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/routledg/cele/2005/00000010/00000002/art00002 Chunglin Kwa, Alexander von Humboldt's invention of the natural landscape, The European Legacy, Vol. 10, No. 2, pp. 149-162, 2005]</ref><ref group = note>[http://www.avhumboldt.net/humboldt/publications/paragraph/did/35/vid/38/cid/244/tid/7698/text/The-description-of-nature-in-its-manifold-richness-of-form-as-a-distinct-branch-of-poetic-literat] "The description of nature in its manifold richness of form, as a distinct branch of poetic literature, was wholly unknown to the Greeks. The landscape appears among them merely as the basil-ground of the picture of which human figures constitute the main subject. Passions, breaking forth into action, riveted their attention almost exclusively." Alexander von Humboldt ''[[Cosmos: a sketch of a physical description of the universe]]'' (translation 1804), Volume 2, Part I, Paragraph 5, Chapter I.</ref> Andrew Jackson Downing was aware of, and sympathetic to, Humboldt's ideas, which therefore influenced American landscape gardening.<ref>See ''Horticulturist'', vol.4, no.2, August 1849, which Downing edited.</ref>
Subsequently, the [[geographer]] [[Otto Schlüter]], in 1908, argued that by defining [[geography]] as a ''Landschaftskunde'' (landscape science) would give geography a logical subject matter shared by no other discipline.<ref>James, P.E & Martin, G (1981) ''All Possible Worlds: A History of Geographical Ideas.'' John Wiley & Sons. New York, p.177.</ref><ref>Elkins, T.H (1989) ''Human and Regional Geography in the German-speaking lands in the first forty years of the Twentieth Century''. Entriken, J. Nicholas & Brunn, Stanley D (Eds) ''Reflections on Richard Hartshorne's The nature of geography''. Occasional publications of the Association of the American Geographers, Washington DC., p. 27.</ref> He defined two forms of landscape: the ''Urlandschaft'' (original landscape) or landscape that existed before major human induced changes and the ''Kulturlandschaft'' (cultural landscape) a landscape created by human culture. Schlüter argued that the major task of geography was to trace the changes in these two landscapes.
The term natural landscape is sometimes used as a synonym for [[wilderness]], but for geographers natural landscape is a scientific term which refers to the [[biological]], [[geological]], [[Climatology|climatological]] and other aspects of a landscape, not the cultural values that are implied by the word wilderness.<ref>"The Trouble with Wilderness; or, Getting Back to the Wrong Nature". William Cronon, ed., ''Uncommon Ground: Rethinking the Human Place in Nature''. (New York: W. W. Norton & Co., 1995), pp. 69–90.</ref>
===The natural and conservation=== Matters are complicated by the fact that the words nature and natural have more than one meaning. On the one hand there is the main dictionary meaning for nature: "The phenomena of the physical world collectively, including plants, animals, the landscape, and other features and products of the earth, as opposed to humans or human creations".<ref>"Nature", ''New Oxford American Dictionary''</ref> On the other hand, there is the growing awareness, especially since [[Charles Darwin]], of humanities biological affinity with nature.<ref>[http://education.seattlepi.com/animals-share-human-dna-sequences-6693.html "Animals That Share Human DNA Sequences", Seattlepi.com]</ref>
The [[Dualism (philosophy of mind)|dualism]] of the first definition has its roots is an "ancient concept", because early people viewed "nature, or the nonhuman world […] as a divine ''Other'', godlike in its separation from humans".<ref>Gregory H. Aplett and David N. Cole, "The Trouble with Naturalness: Rethinking Park and Wilderness Goals" in ''Beyond Naturalness: Rethinking Park and Wilderness Stewardshio in an Era of Rapid Change'' (Washington, DC.: Island Press, 2010), p. 14. They cite William Conron's 1995 essay "The Trouble with Wilderness: or, Getting Back to the Wrong Nature".</ref> In the [[Western culture|West]], Christianity's myth of [[The fall of man|the fall]], that is the expulsion of humankind from the [[Garden of Eden]], where all creation lived in harmony, into an imperfect world, has been the major influence.<ref>Joanne Vining, Melinda Merrick and Emily Price, "The Distinction between Humans and Nature". ''Human Ecology Review'', vol.15, no. 1, 2008, p. 1</ref> [[Cartesian dualism]], from the seventeenth century on, further reinforced this dualistic thinking about nature.<ref>Vining, Merrick and Price, p. 1.</ref> With this [[Dualism (philosophy of mind)|dualism]] goes value judgement as to [[appeal to nature|the superiority of the natural over the artificial]]. Modern science, however, is moving towards a [[holistic]] view of nature.<ref>Maria Kaika, ''City of Flows: Modernity, Nature, and the City''. (New York: Routledge, 2005), p. 4.</ref>
====America==== What is meant by natural, within the American [[conservation movement]], has been changing over the last century and a half.
In the mid-nineteenth century American began to realize that the land was becoming more and more domesticated and wildlife was disappearing. This led to the creation of [[National Park Service|American National Parks]] and other conservation sites.<ref>Gregory H. Aplett and David N. Cole, "The Trouble with Naturalness: Rethinking Park and Wilderness Goals" in ''Beyond Naturalness: Rethinking Park and Wilderness Stewardshio in an Era of Rapid Change'' (Washington, DC.: Island Press, 2010), pp. 14-15.</ref> Initially it was believed that all that was needed to do was to separate what was seen as natural landscape and "avoid disturbances such as logging, grazing, fire and insect outbreaks".<ref name="Aplett and Cole, p. 15">Aplett and Cole, p. 15.</ref> This, and subsequent environmental policy, until recently, was influenced by ideas of the wilderness.<ref>William Cronon, pp. 72-77</ref> However, this policy was not consistently applied, and in [[Yellowstone Park]], to take one example, the existing ecology was altered, firstly by the exclusion of Native Americans and later with the virtual extermination of the wolf population.<ref name="dow">{{cite web |title=Defenders of Wildlife |work=A Yellowstone Chronology |url=http://www.defenders.org/wildlife/wolf/ynpchro.html |accessdate=2007-03-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070607214843/http://www.defenders.org/wildlife/wolf/ynpchro.html |archivedate=7 June 2007}}</ref{{cite book |last=Merchant |first=Carolyn |title=The Columbia Guide to American Environmental History |publisher=Columbia University Press |year=2002 |isbn=978-0-231-11232-1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QQQximQsxSgC |page=148}}</ref>
A century later, in the mid-twentieth century, it began to be believed that the earlier policy of "protection from disturbance was inadequate to preserve park values", and that is that direct human intervention was necessary to restore the landscape of National Parks to its ‘’natural’’ condition.<ref name="Aplett and Cole, p. 15"/> In 1963 the [[Leopold Report]] argued that "A national park should represent a vignette of primitive America".<ref>Aplett and Cole, p. 16.</ref> This policy change eventually led to the restoration of [[History of wolves in Yellowstone|wolves in Yellowstone Park]] in the 1990s.
However, recent research in various disciplines indicates that a pristine natural or "primitive" landscape is a myth, and it now realised that people have been changing the natural into a cultural landscape for a long while, and that there are few places untouched in some way from human influence.<ref>Aplett and Cole, p. 18</ref> The earlier conservation policies were now seen as cultural interventions. The idea of what is natural and what artificial or cultural, and how to maintain the natural elements in a landscape, has been further complicated by the discovery of [[global warming]] and how it is changing natural landscapes.<ref>Aplett and Cole, p. 24</ref>
Also important is a reaction recently amongst scholars against dualistic thinking about nature and culture. Maria Kaika comments: "Nowadays, we are beginning to see nature and culture as intertwined once again – not [[ontologically]] separated anymore […].What I used to perceive as a compartmentalized world, consisting of neatly and tightly sealed, autonomous ‘space envelopes’ (the home, the city, and nature) was, in fact, a messy socio-spatial continuum”.<ref>''City of Flows: Modernity, Nature, and the City''. (New York: Routledge, 2005), p. 4.</ref> And William Cronon argues against the idea of wilderness because it "involves a dualistic vision in which the human is entirely outside the natural"<ref>Cronon, p. 78.</ref> and affirms that "wildness (as opposed to wilderness) can be found anywhere" even "in the cracks of a Manhattan sidewalk".<ref name="Cronon, p. 85">Cronon, p. 85.</ref> According to Cronon we have to "abandon the dualism that sees the tree in the garden as artificial […] and the tree in the wilderness as natural […] Both in some ultimate sense are wild."<ref name="Cronon, p. 85"/> Here he bends somewhat the regular dictionary meaning of wild, to emphasise that nothing natural, even in a garden, is fully under human control.
====Europe==== The landscape of Europe has considerably altered by people and even in an area, like the [[Cairngorm Mountains]] of [[Scotland]], with a low population density, only " the high summits of the [[Cairngorm Mountains]], consist entirely of natural elements.<ref>[http://www.snh.gov.uk/about-scotlands-nature/scotlands-landscapes/what-is-landscape/ [[Scottish Natural Heritage]], ]</ref> These ''high summits'' are of course only part of the Cairngorms, and there are no longer wolves, bears, wild boar or lynx in Scotland's wilderness.<ref>Murray (1973)</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/north_east/6155172.stm | title = Extinct Island Pig Spotted Again | publisher = BBC News | date = 17 November 2006 | accessdate =1 January 2007}}</ref><ref name="Fraser Darling and Boyd 1969 64">Fraser Darling and Boyd (1969) p. 64</ref> The [[Scots pine]] in the form of the [[Caledonian forest]] also covered much more of the Scottish landscape than today.<ref>Steven, H. M. & Carlisle, A. (1959). ''The Native Pinewoods of Scotland''. Oliver and Boyd, Edinburgh</ref>
The [[Swiss National Park]], however, represent a more natural landscape. It was founded in 1914, and is one of the earliest national parks in Europe. Visitors are not allowed to leave the motor road, or paths through the park, make fire or camp. The only building within the park is Chamanna Cluozza, [[mountain hut]]. It is also forbidden to disturb the animals or the plants, or to take home anything found in the park. Dogs are not allowed. Due to these strict rules, the Swiss National Park is the only park in the Alps who has been categorized by the [[IUCN]] as a [[strict nature reserve]], which is the highest protection level.<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=SWI+01&mode=all Parc Suisse Biosphere Reserve]</ref>
==History of natural landscape== No place on the Earth is unaffected by people and their culture. People are part of [[biodiversity]], but human activity affects biodiversity, and this alters the natural landscape.<ref>[http://www.amnh.org/museum/press/feature/biofact.html National Survey Reveals Biodiversity Crisis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070607101209/http://www.amnh.org/museum/press/feature/biofact.html |date=7 June 2007 }} American Museum of Natural History</ref> Mankind have altered landscape to such an extent that few places on earth remain pristine, but once free of human influences, the landscape can return to a natural or near natural state.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u4uDb0H4V5c YouTube, Professor James Lovelock, We can't save the planet, BBC NEWS, 2010/03/30]</ref>
[[File:Wrangell St. Elias National Park.jpg|thumb| [[Glacier]] on the border between [[Alaska]], US, and Canada: [[Kluane-Wrangell-St. Elias-Glacier Bay-Tatshenshini-Alsek]] park system]] Even the remote [[Yukon]] and [[Alaskan]] wilderness, the bi-national [[Kluane-Wrangell-St. Elias-Glacier Bay-Tatshenshini-Alsek]] park system comprising [[Kluane National Park|Kluane]], [[Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve|Wrangell-St Elias]], [[Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve|Glacier Bay]] and [[Tatshenshini-Alsek Park|Tatshenshini-Alsek]] parks, a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]], is not free from human influence, because the [[Kluane National Park]] lies within the traditional territories of the Champagne and Aishihik [[First Nations]] and [[Kluane First Nation]] who have a long history of living in this region. Through their respective Final Agreements with the Canadian Government, they have made into law their rights to harvest in this region.
==Examples of cultural forces== Cultural forces intentionally or unintentionally, have an influence upon the landscape.<ref group = note>[http://lamar.colostate.edu/%7Ehrolston/Technol-vs-Nature-Aberdeen.pdf "It is true that certain human technological actions do have unintended consequences that spread everywhere; there are contagious effects that seep into the nooks and crannies of all nature." Holmes Rolston III, "Technology versus nature, What is natural, Journal of Philosophy and Technology", ''Ends and Means'', Vol 2 No.2 Spring 1998, University of Aberdeen, Edinburgh University Press]</ref> [[Cultural landscapes]] are places or artifacts created and maintained by people. Examples of cultural intrusions into a landscape are: fences, roads, parking lots, sand pits, buildings, hiking trails, management of plants, including the introduction of [[invasive species]], extraction or removal of plants, management of animals, mining, hunting, [[natural landscaping]], farming and forestry, pollution. Areas that might be confused with a natural landscape include [[public park]]s, farms, orchards, artificial lakes and reservoirs, managed forests, golf courses, nature center trails, gardens. [[File:Pony in brecon2.jpg|thumb|A [[Welsh mountain pony]] in the [[Brecon Beacons]] [[National park]], [[Wales]]. Sheep and cattle also graze on this upland]]
==See also== {{portal|Environment}} {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Cityscape]] * [[Land restoration]] * [[Land use]] * [[Landscape art]] * [[National Parks]] * [[Natural environment]] * [[Romantic movement]] * [[Seascape]]s * [[Skyscape art]] * [[Soundscape]] }}
